intro: Theobroma speciosum var. coriaceum, commonly known as the Coriaceum cupuacu, is a species native to the Amazon rainforest. It is a member of the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its large, palmate leaves and showy, yellow-orange flowers. The plant produces elliptical pods that contain seeds used in traditional medicine and as a source of cocoa butter. It thrives in humid, tropical climates with well-drained soil and partial shade. Its botanical features make it an important species for both ecological and economic purposes in its native habitat.
